description: Variable topics in Jewish thought, history, literature, and culture as represented in classified Jewish texts, Jewish law, Jewish ethics, folklore, Hasidism, and Holocaust literature.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Israeli Palestinian Conflict
description: Variable topics in Jewish thought, history, literature, and culture as represented in classified Jewish texts, Jewish law, Jewish ethics, folklore, Hasidism, and Holocaust literature.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Israeli Security Policies
description: Variable topics in Jewish thought, history, literature, and culture as represented in classified Jewish texts, Jewish law, Jewish ethics, folklore, Hasidism, and Holocaust literature.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Old Testament in New
description: Variable topics in Jewish thought, history, literature, and culture as represented in classified Jewish texts, Jewish law, Jewish ethics, folklore, Hasidism, and Holocaust literature.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Religion in the Public Sphere
description: Variable topics in Jewish thought, history, literature, and culture as represented in classified Jewish texts, Jewish law, Jewish ethics, folklore, Hasidism, and Holocaust literature.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies: World of the Vikings and Norse
description: Variable topics in Jewish thought, history, literature, and culture as represented in classified Jewish texts, Jewish law, Jewish ethics, folklore, Hasidism, and Holocaust literature.

name: Individual Work in Jewish Studies
description: For advanced students who desire supplemental reading or research under guidance.

name: Colloquium in Jewish Studies: Jews and Cinema
description: Colloquium in Jewish studies designed to enhance knowledge of the development and significance of Jewish civilization.

name: Landscape Management
description: Explores the relationship between planning and design decision-making and landscape management practices which are, in turn, based on the fundamental principles of ecology and landscape ecology.

name: Planting Design Studio
description: The planting design studio introduces the planting design process, its relationship to the site planning, existing site conditions, project locale and client needs.

name: Design Communications 2
description: Advances the design communication strategies introduced in Design Communications I by further developing skills in digital visualization and communication techniques. Additionally, expanding their skill set to include advanced applications in to include landform and three dimensional space and object modeling and to be introduced to digital fabrication and three dimensional output.

name: Urban Design Studio
description: Design studio emphasizes the physical, social-behavioral, and civil factors involved with the design and planning of towns, cities and the public space found therein. Projects range in scale and complexity including the design of a new urban environment and/or existing urban development.

name: Advanced Design Communication
description: Develop skills in digital visualization and communication techniques, exploring digital media as a landscape architecture tool for design and fabrication; produce high quality perspective drawings and design diagrams using Rhino and Adobe CC, and digital fabrication techniques using UF's Fab Lab.

name: Landscape Construction 1
description: Characteristics of land form and the effects of grading on drainage, soils and location of landscape architectural elements; pavings, low retaining walls; quantification skills.

name: Landscape Architecture Professional Practice
description: Preparation for professional practice and the understanding of the business of landscape architecture in private and public arenas.

name: Senior Independent Project
description: This final semester-long project expands personal interests and talents, hones decision-making abilities, and sharpens professional skills through well-rounded, comprehensive completion of individual projects. Project must be approved by the faculty.

name: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture: Design Communications 2
description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

name: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture: Design Implementation
description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

name: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture: Southeast Field Trip
description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

name: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture: Northeast Field Trip
description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

name: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture: Planting and Site Des Studio
description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

name: Landscape Architecture Internship
description: Internship in a private/public sector office under the direction of a registered landscape architect; required for graduation.

name: Introduction to Secondary English Language Arts Methods
description: The purposes of this course are (a) to make connections among concepts in curriculum and instruction, literacy education, and the teaching of reading and writing, (b) to introduce the processes of planning curriculum, lessons, and activities that are aligned with assessment and that are based on strategies that support and challenge diverse learners, and (c) to build understandings of professional and ethical issues that are of concern to English Language Arts teachers.

name: Special Topics in Latin American History: History of Asylum
description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

name: Special Topics in Latin American History: The Cuban Revolution
description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

name: Special Topics in Latin American History: Reproductive Justice in Americ
description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

name: Special Topics in Latin American History: Brazilian Hy in Lit and Film
description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

name: Science and Technology in Latin American, 1492-Present
description: Introduces the diffusion, acculturation and adaption of scientific ideas, practices and technology by exploring concepts within Latin America.

name: History Research Seminar: Latin America: Revolutions in the Andes
description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

name: History Research Seminar: Latin America: Writing Slaves Lives
description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

name: Introduction to Latin American Studies
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the study of Latin American societies and cultures. Provides general knowledge of Latin America and its people, preparing students for future coursework in Latin American studies. (H or S, and N)

name: Drug Wars and Oil Fortunes in Latin America
description: Examines the historical, comparative, and current dynamics of two global commodities—illicit drugs and licit petroleum. Considers how the presumably separate spheres of legal and illegal commodity exchange have become intertwined and covers the linkages between the Drug War, petroleum extractivism, and United States—Latin America relations.

name: Special Topics in Latin American Studies: Food and Gastronomy in Lat Am
description: Variable topics in Latin American studies.

name: Special Topics in Latin American Studies: Latin American Music
description: Variable topics in Latin American studies.

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Politics of Puerto Rico
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Populism and Fascism
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Global Forests
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Gender, Pol & Human Rts Lat Am
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Politics of US Housing
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Politics of Sports & Stadiums
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Visual Ethno Storytelling
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Reproductive Justice in the Am
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Politics & Poetics of Memory
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Fictions and the Archive
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Brazilian History, Lit & Film
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Latinx U.S. Social Movements
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Latinx Oral Histories
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Env. Justice & Dev. in LatAm
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Int'l Politics of Latin Am
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Latin American Area Seminar: Climate Change & Env Justice
description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

name: Beginning Latin 2
description: The second part of the sequence for those with little or no background in Latin.

name: Beginning Latin 3
description: The third part of the sequence for students with little background in high-school Latin.

name: Beginning Latin 1
description: The first of a 3-semester sequence for students with little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

name: Advanced Residential Landscape Design
description: Sustainable landscape design concepts and practices to create regenerative and resilient residential landscapes that demonstrate advanced design skills and knowledge.

name: Leisure Contemporary Society
description: Examines leisure as a condition of being human, as a cultural mirror and as a social instrument; reflects a wide range of literature from a number of academic disciplines. (S)

name: Principles of Travel and Tourism
description: Overview of the travel and tourism industry; covers historical, behavioral, societal, and business aspects of travel and tourism.

name: Fundamentals of Tourism Planning
description: Examines the planning of tourism services and facilities, including the identification, planning and use of the physical, social and economic resources necessary to develop and support tourism.

name: Hospitality Management
description: Overview of the hospitality industry, including hotel management, food and beverage operations, business and leisure travel markets, convention services, hospitality trends, quest-based customer service strategies and career opportunities.

name: Field Experience in THEM
description: Practical field experience in tourism, hospitality, and event services delivery. Apply skill and knowledge as volunteers and utilize leadership and management skills to enhance participant involvement and agency operations. Prepare a resume, investigate agencies as potential internship sites, and submit the appropriate forms for approval of an internship site.

name: Management & and Supervision of THEM Facilities
description: The management process as it relates to planning and operation of leisure service facilities. Subjects include traditional and contemporary management theory, the management process, legal and financial aspects, risk management and contemporary issues in leisure services management. Facility topics include feasibility studies and design issues.

name: Research Methods in Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management
description: Lays out the foundations for conducting research in tourism, hospitality, event management, sports, business, and social sciences in general. Introduces diverse aspects of research, from setting the theoretical background, to evaluating the results of analyses.

name: Introduction to Linguistics
description: Core areas of linguistics research: phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition.

name: The Sounds of Human Language
description: Emphasizes the sounds employed in languages of the world for a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism underlying the production of speech sounds and the ability to recognize, distinguish and phonetically transcribe speech sounds from an unfamiliar language. Includes investigation of the patterning and functions of sounds in languages of the world and application of the methods of analyzing a language sound system.

name: The Structure of Human Language
description: Investigates word formation processes (morphology) and sentence structure (syntax) in the world's languages. Focuses on vocabulary and tools used to discover and describe patterns in human language. Coursework emphasizes problem solving and working with a wide range of language data.

name: Modern English Structure
description: Studies the grammar of current English from the viewpoint of modern linguistics.

name: Stats for Linguists
description: Introduces the concepts of probability and statistics, with examples chosen mainly from linguistics. Topics include descriptive statistics, comparing means, regression, t-tests, linear mixed models, and basic experimental design.

name: Introduction to Morphology
description: Theory of word structure, derivation and inflection, with examples and problems from a variety of languages. Includes the position of morphology in grammar, the relationship between morphology and grammar, typology, cultural and conceptual categories, and predictions of various theories of morphology. May be taught in conjunction with a graduate course that bears the same title.

name: Gender and Language
description: Language in the construction of sex and gender roles within a culture. Grammaticalization of gender in languages of the world. Interaction of grammatical structures with gender stereotypes. Consequences of these interactions on grammatical structures.

name: Psycholinguistics
description: Basic issues in psycholinguistics, including linguistic principles and psychological mechanisms in language production, comprehension, acquisition and development.

name: Second Language Acquisition
description: The neurolinguistic, psycholinguistic and sociolinguistic bases of second language acquisition in childhood and adulthood.

name: Field Methods
description: Introduction to linguistic fieldwork. Hands-on investigation of the phonetic, phonological, morphological, and syntactic structure of a lesser-known language and the techniques used in the elicitation and analysis of such linguistic data.

name: Introduction to Computational Linguistics
description: Introduces the study of natural language from a computational perspective. Discusses both applied (engineering) and theoretical (cognitive) issues, ranging from speech and language technology to formal aspects of theoretical linguistic models. Covers a brief introduction to programming in Python, and the basics of Natural Language Processing and their applications.

name: Individual Study in Linguistics: INDIVIDUAL STUDY
description: Individual study for linguistics majors.

name: Individual Study in Linguistics
description: Individual study for linguistics majors.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Sociophonetics
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Constructed Languages
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Language Endangerment
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Psycholing of Bilingualism
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Rsch Meth Computat Linguistics
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Social Categories & Ling Knowl
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Sociolinguistics of Writing
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics: Syntax 2
description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Accommodation for senior thesis.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Accommodation for senior thesis.

name: Introduction to Library and Internet Research
description: Learn how to conduct solid and reliable library research. Critical thinking skills are used to find, evaluate and use relevant scholarly resources in a variety of disciplines. This dynamic, hands-on course emphasizes creative thinking and media production tools while exploring the social responsibilities of using digital age information.

name: Introduction to Literature
description: In this course, students will be assigned readings representative of a broad range of literary genres and cultures. These readings will cover a variety of literary movements and historical eras. The readings will include selections from the Western canon. Written analysis of literary works may be required. Students will be provided with opportunities to practice critical interpretation.

name: Introduction to Literature
description: In this course, students will be assigned readings representative of a broad range of literary genres and cultures. These readings will cover a variety of literary movements and historical eras. The readings will include selections from the Western canon. Written analysis of literary works may be required. Students will be provided with opportunities to practice critical interpretation.

name: Survey of World Literature: Ancient to Renaissance
description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)

name: Survey of World Literature: 17th Century to Modern
description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)

name: The Forms of Narrative: Race and Narrative Form
description: A close reading and critical analysis of representative forms and styles of narrative, to improve the student's ability to study narrative structures and theories of narrative. Refer to department website.

name: Studies in Modern Drama: African American Theatre
description: Representative selections from continental, British, and American playwrights. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Jewish Literature: Make Love, Not War
description: Variable topics in the Jewish literary experience, from the biblical narrative and classical tales to Yiddish and Hebrew literature, the modern European novel, and American Jewish fiction.

name: The Bible as Literature
description: Literary analysis from the Hebrew and Christian Bibles with an emphasis on poetry and narrative.

name: Interdisciplinary Topics in Literature: Poetics of JusticeLaw,Lit,Film
description: Interdisciplinary variable-topics study of the vital relationship between literature and other creative arts, other humanistic disciplines, or the sciences and technology. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Interdisciplinary Topics in Literature: Ethics, Utopia & Dystopia
description: Interdisciplinary variable-topics study of the vital relationship between literature and other creative arts, other humanistic disciplines, or the sciences and technology. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: World English Language Literatures: Intro to Postcolonial Studies
description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the diverse English language literary traditions, including those of Ireland, Scotland, India, Nigeria, the Caribbean, Canada, and Australia. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Postcolonial Literature, Culture and Theory: Literature and Colonialism
description: Variable topics explore the issues, questions, and themes raised in the rich literature, culture, and theory that emerge as a response to and in contestation of the experiences of the colonial and postcolonial worlds. Refer to department website for offered content.

name: Golden Age of Children's Literature
description: Origins and evolution of the Anglo-American tradition in literature for young readers, 1720-1920, with an emphasis on the Victorian era. Authors may include Defoe, Scott, Cooper, Dickens, Alcott, Twain and Stevenson.

name: Issues and Methods in Cultural Studies
description: Introduces the issues and methodology used in cultural studies and encourages the exploration of a number of methods by which culture is analyzed, understood, and disseminated. Refer to department website.

name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language: Jews and Cinema
description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language: Ukraine and Jews
description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language: Forgery, Painting, Film
description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language: Wicked Women
description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language: Feminist Fiction
description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language: Chinese Film and Media
description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

name: Roman Elegy and Lyric
description: Selected poems of Catullus, Horace, Tibullus, Propertius or Ovid. (H and N)

name: Introduction to Real Analysis 1
description: Theory of real numbers, functions of one variable, sequences, limits, continuity and differentiation; continuity and differentiability of functions of several variables. Those who plan to do graduate work in mathematics should take MAA 4211. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4102, MAA 4211, or MAA 5104.

name: Introduction to Real Analysis 2
description: Continues the advanced calculus for engineers and physical scientists sequence. Theory of integration, transcendental functions and infinite series. MAA 4102 is not recommended for those who plan to do graduate work in mathematics; these students should take MAA 4212. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4103, MAA 4212 and MAA 5105.

name: Real Analysis and Advanced Calculus 2
description: Continues the advanced calculus sequence in limits, differentiation, integration and series. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4212, MAA 4103 and MAA 5105.

name: Introduction to Modern Analysis 2
description: Continues the modern analysis sequence discussing the topology of metric spaces, numerical sequences and series, continuity, differentiation, the Riemann-Stieltjes integral, sequences and series of functions, the Stone-Weierstrass theorem, functions of several variables, Stokes' theorem and the Lebesgue theory. Credit will be given for, at most, MAA 4227 or MAA 5229.

name: Functions of a Complex Variable
description: Complex numbers, analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations, harmonic functions, elementary functions, integration, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, infinite series, residues and poles, conformal mapping. Credit will be given for, at most, MAA 4402 or MAA 5404.

name: Basic College Algebra
description: In this course, students will develop problem solving skills, critical thinking, computational proficiency, and contextual fluency through the study of equations, functions, and their graphs. Emphasis will be placed on quadratic, exponential, and logarithmic functions. Topics will include solving equations and inequalities, definition and properties of a function, domain and range, transformations of graphs, operations on functions, composite and inverse functions, basic polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, and applications.

name: Trigonometry
description: Exponential and logarithmic functions, trigonometry and analytic and additional applications of trigonometry. (M)

name: Precalculus Algebra
description: College algebra, functions, coordinate geometry, exponential and logarithmic functions. (M)

name: Precalculus Algebra and Trigonometry
description: College algebra, functions, coordinate geometry, exponential and logarithmic functions, and trigonometry. Fast-paced review of algebra and trigonometry to prepare for calculus. Assumes prior knowledge of intermediate algebra (Algebra 2) and trigonometry. (M)

name: Survey of Calculus 1
description: Geometric and heuristic approach to calculus; differentiation and integration of simple algebraic and exponential functions; applications to graphing, marginal analysis, optimization, areas and volumes. (M)

name: Survey of Calculus 2
description: Sequences, geometric and Taylor series; systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, matrices, determinants and vectors; partial differentiation, multiple integrals; applications to marginal analysis, least-squares and Lagrange multipliers. (M)

name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1
description: In this course, students will develop problem solving skills, critical thinking, computational proficiency, and contextual fluency through the study of limits, derivatives, and definite and indefinite integrals of functions of one variable, including algebraic, exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions, and applications. Topics will include limits, continuity, differentiation and rates of change, optimization, curve sketching, and introduction to integration and area.

name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2
description: Techniques of integration; applications of integration; differentiation and integration of inverse trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions; sequences and series. (M) Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAC 2312, MAC 2512 and MAC 3473.

name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 3
description: Solid analytic geometry, vectors, partial derivatives and multiple integrals. (M) Credit will be given for, at most, MAC 2313 or MAC 3474.

name: Intro to Computational Math
description: Introduces mathematical computation and the Python programming language. Emphasizes using mathematical algorithms to solve problems in analysis, number theory, combinatorics, algebra, linear algebra, numerical analysis, and probability.

name: Introduction to Combinatorics 2
description: Matching theory, block designs, finite projective planes and error-correcting codes. Does not require MAD 4203.

name: Graph Theory
description: Theory and applications of graphs including connectivity, planarity, coloration, algorithms, and network flow.

name: Introduction to Numerical Analysis
description: Numerical integration, nonlinear equations, linear and nonlinear systems of equations, differential equations and interpolation.

name: Explorations Teaching Secondary Mathematics and Science
description: Introduces prospective teachers to teaching secondary mathematics and science (grades 6-12).

name: Teaching Elementary Mathematics Lab
description: An inquiry-based math lab to accompany MAE4310. Focused on hands-on activities related to foundational concepts in elementary mathematics, with an emphasis on family/community experiences, equity and social justice issues, and relationships to science, technology, engineering, and/or the arts.

name: Principles of Management
description: Fundamentals of management underlying the solution of problems of organization and operation of business enterprises. (S)

name: Organizations: Structure and Behavior
description: Individual group and organizational issues that affect and shape businesses. Topics include individual differences, motivation, communication, decision making, leadership, power, organizational structure and design and change.

name: Human Resource Management
description: Major human resource management functional areas. Topics include organizational employment planning, employment regulation, job analysis, performance assessment, recruitment and selection, training and development, employee/labor relations and compensation.

name: Operations and Supply Chain Management
description: Managerial concepts and quantitative tools required in the design, operation, and control of production systems and their relationship to business functions.

name: Strategic Management
description: Evaluation of the key functions of organizations and integration of these functions to achieve competitive advantages. Topics include strategic formulation, implementation and evaluation.

name: Elementary Differential Equations
description: First-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations. (M)

name: Probability Theory and Stochastic Processes 2
description: Random walks and Poisson processes, martingales, Markov chains, Brownian motion, stochastic integrals and Ito's formula.

name: Differential Equations for Engineers and Physical Scientists
description: The second course in differential equations. Topics include systems of linear differential equations, stability theory and phase plane analysis, power series solutions of differential equations, Sturm-Liouville boundary-value problems and special functions. Credit will be given for, at most, MAP 4305 or MAP 5304.

name: Elements of Partial Differential Equations
description: Introduces second-order linear partial differential equations (heat, wave and Laplace equations), separation of variables in PDEs, Sturm-Liouville eigenvalue problems, method of eigenfunction expansions (Fourier analysis) and Green's functions. Possible introduction to first-order PDEs and the method of characteristics. Credit will be given for, at most, MAP 4341 or MAP 5345.

name: Fourier Analysis
description: Introduces linear systems and transforms; Laplace, Fourier and Z transforms and their mutual relationship; convolutions. Operational calculus; computational methods including the fast Fourier transform; second-order stationary processes and their autocorrelation functions; and problems of interpolation, extrapolation, filtering and smoothing of second-order stationary processes.

name: Retail Management Seminar
description: Weekly lectures feature a different executive making a presentation in their area of expertise. Addresses major issues in retailing. Discussions of retailing career opportunities and career paths.

name: Sales Seminar
description: Overview of selling and managing the sales function to achieve the growth targets of a business; highlights the importance of the sales function in a firm and how it contributes to the achievement of the firm’s strategic objectives.

name: Special Topics: Careers in Marketing
description: Projects related to business in marketing as approved by the college.

name: Principles of Marketing
description: Functions, institutions and methods of marketing goods and services. Relates marketing to the larger economic structure and emphasizes the importance of the consumer.

name: Introduction to Retailing Systems and Management
description: Functions, institutions and activities of retailing goods and services.

name: Professional Selling
description: Basic survey in professional selling. Teaches the importance of the selling role and provides basic professional selling skills; begins the preparation for a future role in sales or sales management.

name: Consumer Behavior
description: Emphasizes both descriptive and conceptual analysis of consumer behavior with a focus on theory and research essential to an understanding of individual choice behavior. Makes intensive use of contributions from the social and behavioral science literatures.

name: Sales Management
description: Principles, methods, and problems relating to the management of a sales force. Selection and training, organization, compensation and stimulation, and control.

name: Marketing Management
description: Development and analysis of overall marketing strategies involving product and brand development, channels of distribution, pricing, and promotion with consideration of marketplace conditions and related factors affecting implementation and execution.

name: Special Topics: Digital Marketing
description: Selected rotating topics in marketing management, research and theory.

name: Sales Internship
description: Teaches the importance of the sales function in a firm and how the sales function contributes to the achievement of the firm’s strategic objectives. Using participative on-the-job learning methods, gain an overview of the sales function in a firm and gain a sense of the reality of business situations, which aids success in virtually any sales-oriented career assignment.

name: Honors Thesis
description: A thesis is required for magna cum laude or summa cum laude designation. To qualify, students normally have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made) and have at least a 3.6 GPA at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's department.

name: Computational Linear Algebra
description: Linear equations, matrices and determinants. Vector spaces and linear transformations. Inner products and eigenvalues. Emphasizes computational aspects of linear algebra.

name: Linear Algebra 1
description: Linear equations, matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues and inner-product spaces. Includes both theory and computational skills. Develops the ability to reason through, and coherently write, proofs of theorems. For math majors, this course serves as a transition from a study of techniques into more conceptual math; for engineering and science majors, it serves also as a coherent foundation in linear algebra.

name: Linear Algebra for Data Science
description: A second course in linear algebra, focusing on topics that are the most essential for data science. Introduces theory and numerical methods required for large data-sets and machine learning. Topics include LU, QR, and singular-value decompositions; conditioning and stability; the DFT and filters; deep learning; fully connected and convolutional nets.

name: Introduction to Number Theory
description: Introduces elementary number theory and its applications to computer science and cryptology. Divisibility, primes, Euclidean Algorithm, congruences, Chinese Remainder Theorem, Euler-Fermat Theorem and primitive roots. Selected applications to decimal fractions, continued fractions, computer file storage and hashing functions, and public-key cryptography.

name: Abstract Algebra 1
description: Sets and mappings, groups and subgroups, homomorphisms and isomorphisms, permutations, rings and domains, arithmetic properties of domains, and fields. Requires facility in writing proofs.

name: Abstract Algebra 2
description: A second course in Abstract Algebra, focusing on Galois Theory, the algebraic theory of fields and polynomial equations. Introduces concepts of abstract algebra used in settling famous historical problems including the problems of angle trisection and duplication of cubes by ruler and compass constructions, and the insolubility of polynomial equations of the fifth degree by radicals.

name: Microbiology
description: Role of microorganisms in chemical transformations, disease, public health, and agriculture. Fundamental concepts are discussed, followed by beneficial and harmful actions of microorganisms as they affect our lives. Not acceptable for admission to advanced microbiology courses nor for the preprofessional curricula required for the medical/veterinary sciences.

name: Microbiology Laboratory
description: Laboratory exercises demonstrate biochemical transformations and present methods for studying microbial properties. Not acceptable for admission to advanced microbiology courses nor for the preprofessional curricula required for the medical/veterinary sciences.

name: Basic Biology of Microorganisms
description: Introduces the principles and techniques of microbiology, genetics, taxonomy, biochemistry and ecology and microorganisms. Also studies virology, immunology, and the pathogenicity of microorganisms. (B)

name: Laboratory for Basic Biology of Microorganisms
description: Laboratory exercises on the structure, nutrition, and growth of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Includes isolation and classification of representative microorganisms.

name: Principles of Microbiology
description: Introduces the principles and techniques of microbiology, genetics, taxonomy, biochemistry, and ecology of microorganisms. Required of all majors and students who will enroll in more advanced courses in the Department of Microbiology and Cell Science.

name: Principles of Microbiology Laboratory
description: Laboratory techniques on the structure, nutrition, biochemistry, genetics, and growth of microorganisms. Required of all majors and students who will enroll in more advanced courses in the Department of Microbiology and Cell Science.

name: Astrobiology
description: Examines the origin, evolution, and future of life in our solar system. Include planetary habitability, astrobiogeochemistry, microbial life, and human spaceflight.

name: Advanced Microbiology Laboratory
description: Application of immunological, molecular biological and microbial techniques to the isolation, identification, and characterization of bacteria and viruses.

name: Careers for Impact in Microbiology and Cell Science
description: Provides connections into a variety of microbiology and cell science careers, and hones essential networking and communication skills through practical application exercises. A portfolio will be created to identify and obtain suitable experiential learning and career opportunities.

name: Innovation Project Management for Life Sciences
description: Provides practical tools to manage innovation projects typical of life science research and development. Discusses challenges and methodologies associated with developing objectives, preparing project plans, establishing metrics, defining responsibilities, as well as mitigating risks and dealing with uncertainties. Also strengthens skills for strategic prioritization, time management, meeting facilitation, and communication to promote an innovative culture.

name: Bacterial Pathogens
description: Host-microbe relationships in the diseases of humans and animals, including the virulence characteristics of bacterial pathogens, the techniques used in their isolation/identification, and molecular approaches to the study of their virulence.

name: Antimicrobial Resistance
description: Covers content related to antimicrobial resistance: the origins of antimicrobial resistance, dissemination, mechanisms, therapeutics, and impact on healthcare, agriculture, and the environment. Mainly concentrates on resistance in bacteria, but will also discuss other organisms, including viruses, parasites, fungi, and cancer.

name: The Microbiome
description: Increase knowledge, appreciation, and use of genomics pertaining to the breadth of microbial diversity across a wide variety of organisms and habitats using methods that do not require culturing of the myriad of inhabitants. Use tools, practice analysis, and interpretation of genomic data sets to analyze different microbiomes.

name: Computational Genomics and Epigenomics
description: Genomics and epigenomics utilize high-throughput sequencing technologies in understanding biology questions. The primary goal is to introduce history, theory, latest advances, and computational approaches in (epi)genomics for conducting large-scale genomic analyses. Topics include sequence alignment, genome assembly and annotation, variant identification, transcriptomics, small RNAs, DNA methylation, histone modification, open chromatin region, and 3D chromatin interaction.

name: Probiotics
description: Covers the use of microorganisms to promote a health status in the host and provides a conceptual background in microbiology and immunology for the use of microorganisms for the prevention or treatment of animal and human diseases.

name: General Virology
description: Nature of viruses and mechanisms of infection and replication, including bacterial, animal, and plant viruses.

name: Introduction to the Professions of Medicine
description: A web-based course about the medical field. Online lectures are presented by medical students, residents and practicing physicians who take students through various aspects of the medical profession.

name: Medicine and the Law
description: The importance of the law and its impact on the way medicine is practiced in the United States, presented from academics and practicing attorneys and physicians.

name: Introduction to Medical Bioethics
description: Bioethical issues facing the nation and world and the impact of these issues in medicine and research. Also includes the importance of integrated, collaborative research and the professionalism expected within the healthcare and scientific communities.

name: Diseases of Eating
description: A web-based course that focuses on anorexia, bulimia and obesity and emphasizes societal issues associated with these disorders. Written assignments are opinion-based, encouraging the student to think about these disorders on a broad scale.

name: Castles and Cloisters: An Introduction to Medieval Communities
description: Studies monastic and courtly-chivalric communities as these evolved in the Middle Ages. Explores architecture, art, literature, and music illustrate how different monastic and chivalric communities saw the world and their place in it.

name: Palaces and Cities: An Introduction to Early Modern Communities
description: Explores the new kind of European culture that emerges with early modern residential palaces and cities. The study of seminal texts in poetry, politics and theology, and of early modern cities and palaces shows the new operant principle in cultural processes to be the primacy of the individual. (H)

name: Variable Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: Chinese Martial Arts Fiction
description: Provides intermediate study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Variable Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: Byzantine History
description: Provides intermediate study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Variable Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: World of the Vikings and Norse
description: Provides intermediate study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Special Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: THE QUR'AN AS LITERATURE
description: Advanced study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Special Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: The Viking Experience
description: Advanced study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Special Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: Holy War
description: Advanced study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Special Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies: Present State Ottoman Empire
description: Advanced study in medieval and early modern studies.

name: Introduction to Weather and Climate
description: A course for non-science students interested in understanding the phenomena of daily weather. Several principles of physics are introduced. (P)

name: Atmospheric Dynamics 1
description: This course covers the forces that govern atmospheric motion; acceleration in rotating curvilinear coordinates; momentum, continuity, and energy equations; scale analysis; geostrophic, gradient, and thermal winds; natural coordinates; circulation and vorticity theorems; Reynolds stresses; Prandtl and Ekman layers; and developing baroclinic systems.

name: Weather Briefing
description: Learn to prepare and present a daily weather briefing. Briefings will demonstrate the ability to synthesize weather information on all scales, prepare a forecast, and communicate this clearly and succinctly to an audience.

name: Mesoscale Meteorology
description: Covers the major dynamic and thermodynamic processes of the atmosphere that govern the structure, development, and evolution of weather systems generally smaller than those of the synoptic scale.

name: Atmospheric Teleconnections
description: Atmospheric teleconnections are recurring large-scale patterns of pressure and circulation anomalies. They can influence temperature, rainfall, storm tracks and jet stream location and intensity. Examines how these patterns were discovered, how the index that characterizes the phase of each teleconnection is calculated and the weather associated with different phases.

name: Capstone in Meteorology
description: Complete a team project addressing a common meteorological job task, which requires the integration of the core subfields of meteorology and their application to a sector of the weather enterprise. Create a resume, cover letter, and portfolio of completed work in preparation for the next career stage.

name: Mathematical Thinking
description: In this course, students will utilize multiple means of problem solving through student-centered mathematical exploration. The course is designed to teach students to think more effectively and increase their problem-solving ability through practical application and divergent thinking. This course is appropriate for students in a wide range of disciplines/programs.

name: Sets and Logic
description: Examples of sets, operations on sets, set algebra, Venn diagrams, truth tables, tautologies, applications to mathematical arguments, and mathematical induction. Can also be very useful for prospective and in-service secondary and middle school teachers. Taking one, but not both, of MAS 3300 or MHF 3202 is required of mathematics majors.

name: Elements of Set Theory
description: Basic axioms and concepts of set theory. Students present proofs. Credit will be given for, at most, MHF 4102 or MHF 5107.

name: Special Topics: Human Sexuality
description: Topics vary.

name: Special Topics: Mindful Living
description: Topics vary.

name: Introduction to Media and Communications
description: Introduces the tools, resources and academic and extra-curricular activities offered by the College of Journalism and Communications. Includes lessons on the history and organization of the college and academic and career preparation.

name: Writing Fundamentals for Communicators
description: One-third of the course is to ensure students have sufficient skill in grammar and punctuation to write with clarity. In two-thirds of the course, students put principles of good writing into practice with short writing assignments that have real-world applications.

name: Data Literacy for Communicators
description: Numeracy which enables data literacy; to use, evaluate, and communicate numbers in situations commonly faced in advertising, journalism, public relations, and telecommunications.

name: Media, Cultures, and Identity
description: Examines the role of media in facilitating, challenging, and enabling power dynamics as well as shaping identity in the United States and globally. Looks at various media forms and constructions of race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, and ability. Analyses the relationship between media, identity and power, as well as individual role as a media consumer.

name: Introduction to Media and Sports
description: Introduces sports professions relative to opportunities, responsibilities and current issues involving sports media professionals. Topics include distinctions among careers in sports media, including sports journalism and communications, values, ethics and issues related to race, gender and sexual orientation, and emerging media.

name: Personal Branding for Communicators
description: Professional development course that stresses how to communicate and connect as professionals. Emphasizes mastery of writing, speaking, presentation and employment-seeking skills, working with media, handling media interviews and using social media to establish a professional identity.

name: Ethics and Problems in Mass Communications
description: A cross-disciplinary introduction to ethics-relevant situations faced by media professionals. Topics include professional standards of conduct, audience representation and engagement and issues associated with the production, presentation and delivery of messages that reflect the best interests of audiences, clients and stakeholders.

name: Sports Media Law and Ethics
description: Instruction and analysis of laws, cases and legal and ethical issues related to sports and media. Gain a working knowledge of legal and ethical issues and recent court decisions, and develop critical analytical perspectives on actual examples of recent sports media legal and ethical problems.

name: Media Entrepreneurship
description: Introduces media entrepreneurship with a focus on how digital technologies are transforming industries. Work in teams to develop new digital media businesses. Develop and pitch ideas, explore market analysis, develop business and financial plans, and study social media strategies.

name: Communications on the Internet
description: History, development, and current state of online communications from teletext to the World Wide Web. Focuses on how online services relate to mass media in the past, present, and future. Analyzes content methods, audiences, and income sources. Create online projects related to mass communication.

name: Consumer and Audience Analytics
description: Provides practical analytical skill-sets, benefiting those who plan careers in analytics/research, social media, media business, advertising/marketing, and public relations.

name: Media and Politics
description: Provides an understanding of the role of the media in the political system. Topics include televised debates, political advertising, political journalism, internet, and alternative media.

name: Social Media and Society
description: Explores the structure and consequences of the growing presence of social media networks. Addresses such areas as privacy, democracy, health care, commerce, entertainment, and journalism.

name: Rock 'N Roll and American Society Part 1: ROCK/ROLL & AMERICA
description: Studies the role of popular music in American culture. Not a music course but a look at the effects of recorded sound on popular culture. Part 1 emphasizes rock 'n roll and its impact from 1954-1970. Part 2 covers 1970 to the present.

name: Rock 'N' Roll and American Society Part 2
description:
Studies the role of popular music in American culture. It is not a music course but
a look at the effects of recorded sound on popular culture. Part 1 emphasizes rock 'n' roll and its impact from 1954-1970. Part 2 covers 1970 to 1990.

name: Law of Mass Communication
description: Understanding the law, which guarantees and protects the privileges and defines the responsibilities of the mass media. Includes problems of constitutional law, libel, privacy, and governmental regulations.

name: World Communication Systems
description: Delves into the historical roots, technology, and trends shaping global communication systems. Equips students to analyze media tools and approaches worldwide.

name: Basic Leadership
description: Study and application of the Army ROTC Leadership Development Program (LDP). Instruction includes theory and application of leadership principles, competencies and dimensions. Individual leadership is developed through hands-on instruction in basic, individual military skills. Introduces students to leadership attributes and the application of those attributes in and out of the classroom. Students must register for and attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory (MSL 1002L).

name: Freshman Leadership Laboratory
description: Laboratory consists of a two-hour block of instruction that directly supports freshman classroom instruction. Participation in at least one weekend field training session, one community service project and two army physical fitness tests are required.

name: Leadership and Teamwork Techniques
description: The future leader through classroom instruction, laboratory application and an in-depth look at basic troop/organization leadership principles and skills. Provides training on the basics of rifle marksmanship and instruction on the principles of modern warfare and effective writing. Students must register for and attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory.

name: Sophomore Leadership Laboratory
description: Laboratory consists of a two-hour block of instruction that directly supports sophomore classroom instruction. Participation in at least one weekend field training session, one community service project and two army physical fitness tests are required.

name: Leadership and Ethics
description: Improves cadet proficiency in those military subjects necessary to meet minimum standards of technical competence and self-confidence required of a junior officer in the US Army. Prepares cadets for participation at ROTC advanced camp. Major emphasis during course is physical training and field training exercises. Student must attend a weekly two-hour leadership laboratory and participate in physical fitness sessions given at times other than normal class sessions.

name: Geometry
description: Axiomatic treatment of topics in Euclidean, non-Euclidean, projective geometry and (time permitting) fractal geometry. Particularly useful for prospective secondary-school mathematics teachers.

name: Elements of Topology 2
description: Continues the basic concepts of general topology. Credit will be given for, at most, MTG 4303 or MTG 5317.

name: Composition Skills 2
description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

name: Composition Skills 4
description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through use of finale.

name: Composition 2
description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

name: Composition 4
description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

name: Composition of Electroacoustic Music
description: Continuation of MUC 4313. Projects in electroacoustic music dealing with real-time, interactivity, live-electronic and solo digital media music composition issues.

name: Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 2
description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4441, Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 1.

name: Senior Composition Recital
description: Organization and presentation of a recital of original compositions.

name: Exploring Music Teaching and Learning
description: Introductory overview of music teaching as a profession. For those majoring in music education and those who are interested in a possible career as a music educator.

name: String Skills 2
description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the lower string instruments: cello and double bass.

name: Woodwind Skills 2
description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for alto saxophone, bassoon and oboe.

name: Brass Skills 2
description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments, other than those studied in MUE 3460.

name: Percussion Skills
description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for percussion instruments.

name: Music Learning with Technology
description: Explores the role of digital technologies in creating, performing, and responding to music, with applications to the practice of K-12 music educators and the cultivation of lifelong music learning and participation.

name: Music in Secondary Schools
description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in the secondary school.

name: Literature and Arranging for School Choirs
description: Become familiar with techniques and approaches for selecting and programming literature for K-12 performing ensembles. Introduces fundamental techniques used to create arrangements of choral and vocal works in order to better meet the needs of individual singers or ensembles. Also addresses arranging for instruments.

name: Literature and Arranging for Instrumental Ensembles
description: Techniques for selecting, programming, and arranging music for school instrumental ensembles. Overview of repertoire and arranging techniques including genres, established works, composers, and publishers; pedagogical and practical considerations related to the selection and modification of music. Discussion of relevant copyright laws.

name: Music Student Teaching Seminar
description: Principles and practices of developing, teaching, and administering K-12 public school music programs.

name: Choral Conducting and Materials
description: Basic techniques of choral conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic choral materials.

name: Introduction to World Musics
description: Introduction to musics of non-western cultures in comparison with music of Western European civilizations; the nature of music and the realm of ethnomusicology. (H and N)

name: Popular Music in the USA: From Ragtime to Hip-Hop and Beyond
description: Surveys the musical styles, artists, audiences, and eras of American popular music in relation to the social, cultural, political, and historical contexts in which they emerged. Gives special attention to the diversity and intersecting nature of musical voices in the USA through the examination of musical styles including rock, rhythm and blues, country, punk, hip-hop, salsa, and beyond.

name: Music History Survey 1
description: A survey of music literature, styles, and techniques from antiquity to c. 1750. Examines representative repertoire from historical, theoretical, and cultural contexts and develops critical thinking skills in reading, writing, analysis, and listening.

name: Music History Survey 2
description: Surveys music literature, styles, and techniques from c. 1750 to the present day, and examines representative repertoire from historical, theoretical, and cultural contexts. Also develops critical-thinking skills in reading, writing, analysis, and listening.

name: Latin American Music
description: The variable musical expressions of Latin America (including the Caribbean), their historical formations and social importance. (H and N)

name: History of Jazz
description: From African, Latin American, and Black American sources through contemporary development.

name: Music and Audience
description: Considers the role and function of the audience in conjunction with the symphony, opera, and ballet. Historical readings cover what audiences were like in the Classical Period, Romantic Era, and the Twentieth Century, and major masterworks of those time periods are discussed. The modern audience is considered by discussing recent publications in various mediums and attending two live concerts.

name: Special Topics in Music History: Music & Disability Studies
description: Rotating topics of current or special interest to students or instructors.

name: Special Topics in Music History: MUSIC & MOURNING
description: Rotating topics of current or special interest to students or instructors.

name: Special Topics in Music History: MUSIC & SOCIETY IN MID EAST
description: Rotating topics of current or special interest to students or instructors.

name: Experiencing Music
description: In this course, students will survey the history of classical music from antiquity to the modern period, focusing on Western music. The curriculum may also integrate a variety of popular and global styles where appropriate.

name: Percussion Literature Seminar
description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for solo percussion and percussion ensemble.

name: Found Music Business
description: This course is intended (1) to foster a comprehensive and chronological understanding of the music business, and (2) to observe how rapid changes in the global music industry challenge music professionals and music business organizations to become more entrepreneurial in their planning and practice.

name: Concert Band
description: Performance of general and popular band literature. (H)

name: Symphonic Band
description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature. (H)

name: Wind Symphony
description: Performance of wind ensemble literature. (H)

name: University Orchestra
description: Standard orchestra literature. (H)

name: University Choir
description: An advanced choral group providing specialized study performance opportunities for vocally qualified students. (H)

name: Women's Chorale
description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire. (H)

name: Men's Glee Club
description: Vocal training and public performance of tenor-bass chorus repertoire. Course literature is drawn from a variety of historical periods (including selections from the Western canon), cultures, and musical styles, presenting students with varied perspectives and experiences. Students explore the key elements of the literature including the origin, historical context, and form of song texts, compositional techniques, and performance practices.

name: Choral Union
description: Mixed choral ensemble open to students, faculty, staff, and local residents who have previous choral experience. Course literature is drawn from a variety of historical periods, cultures, and musical styles, presenting students with varied perspectives and experiences.

name: Percussion Ensemble
description: The study and performance of ensemble literature for percussion instruments. (H)

name: Jazz Bands
description: Standard and experimental jazz ensembles. A jazz laboratory. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: PAZENI SAUTI AFRICA CHOIR
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: JACARE BRAZIL VOCAL
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: JACARE BRAZIL PERCUSSION
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: CHINESE ENSEMBLE
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: JACARE BRAZIL INSTRUMENTAL
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: AFRICAN POP ENSEMBLE
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: MUNDO FLAMENCO
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: World Music Ensemble: CLASSICAL PERSIAN ENSEMBLE
description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

name: Commercial Music Ensemble
description: Provides the tools and experience necessary to excel as musicians in the commercial music world. Analyze, study, arrange, and perform a variety of commercial styles including rock, pop, jazz, funk, alternative, country, soul, R&B, Latin, World, and more.

name: Concert Band
description: Performance of general and popular band literature.

name: Symphonic Band
description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature.

name: Wind Symphony
description: Performance of wind ensemble literature. (H)

name: University Orchestra
description: Standard orchestra literature. (H)

name: University Choir
description: An advanced choral group providing specialized study performance opportunities for vocally qualified students. (H)

name: Women's Chorale
description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire.

name: Men's Glee Club
description: Vocal training and public performance of standard male chorus repertoire.

name: University Chamber Singers
description: Study and performance of early and contemporary vocal literature. (H)

name: Choral Union
description: Mixed choral ensemble open to students, faculty, staff, and local residents who have previous choral experience. Course literature is drawn from a variety of historical periods, cultures, and musical styles, presenting students with varied perspectives and experiences.

name: New Music Ensemble
description: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire for small ensembles written in the 20th and 21st centuries.

name: New Music Ensemble: NEW MUSIC VOCAL ENSEMBLE
description: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire for small ensembles written in the 20th and 21st centuries.

name: Jazz Bands
description: Standard and experimental jazz ensembles. A jazz laboratory.

name: Jazz Chamber Music 1
description: Small group ensemble performance experience in the jazz idiom. Students will memorize jazz standards and learn melody interpretation techniques, rhythmic techniques to communicate to other members of the ensemble and small group compositional techniques for harmonizing jazz standards and original compositions.

name: Ensemble Participation
description: Ensemble of variable instrumentation and/or voices performing traditional and contemporary repertoire. For upper-division students who have completed required credits of ensemble participation or elective credits for their degree program, this ensemble exists to allow them to continue performing in ensembles without impacting semester load credits, or excess hours credits. This course allows students from any degree to continue participation in ensembles in support of the university.

name: Opera Workshop
description: Study and performance of works from opera and operetta.

name: Recital Attendance
description: Attendance at concerts and recitals. Check the School of Music student's handbook for specific attendance requirements.

name: An Echo of the Invisible World: Exploring the Relationship Between Music & Spirituality
description: Examines the relationship between music and spirituality, within and outside the context of organized religion. Consider the underlying philosophies in spiritual music and practices, compare them to contemporary American culture, and address their own beliefs and practices through selected case studies and projects.

name: French Diction
description: A French diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

name: German Diction
description: A German diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

name: Music Theory 1
description:
Studies rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord
progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and seventh chords.

name: Music Theory 2
description: Rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, singing and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and diatonic seventh chords.

name: Jazz Aural Skills 1
description: This course teaches students how to aurally recognize commercial chords, standard chord progressions and recognize the scales used in improvisation. This course is a hybrid course with only 7 in class meetings. The course utilizes online resources and instructional videos and online aural quizzes and weekly aural skills drills.

name: Aural Skills 1
description: First of a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight singing and ear training. Singing techniques are taught at the beginning of the course.

name: Aural Skills 2
description: Second of a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight singing and ear training.

name: Commercial Music Theory and Practice 1
description: Provides an intermediate theoretical understanding of jazz and commercial music harmony, jazz chord symbols, common jazz scales and modes, articulations, blues forms, piano voicings, the basics of tune writing, and techniques in accurately memorizing jazz and commercial standards. Online resources include online platform, flash cards, worksheets and 35 instructional videos. This course is recommended for all musicians who pursue a deeper understanding of commercial music.

name: Commercial Music Theory and Practice 2
description: Building upon concepts and skills learned in the first course in the series, the second course covers an advanced theoretical understanding of jazz and commercial harmony, jazz chord symbols, common jazz scales and modes, jazz articulations, blues forms, piano voicings, the basics of tune writing, and techniques in accurately memorizing jazz and commercial standards. Online resources include online platform, flash cards, worksheets, and 35 instructional videos.

name: Music Theory 4
description:
The study of the materials and structures of tonal and post-tonal music through
reading, listening, model composition, and music analysis.

name: Aural Skills 4
description:
Fourth in a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight
singing and ear training.

name: Form and Analysis 2
description: Analysis of contrapuntal forms of canon, motet and fugue; study of musical forms in the 20th century.

name: Jazz Arranging 1
description: This course provides instruction in jazz composition and arranging as well as the basic techniques for commercial song writing. Students will study chord movement, melodic development and composition techniques for various styles of music. Students will complete several small group arrangements and original jazz compositions.

name: Jazz Arranging 2
description: This course provides instruction in jazz composition and arranging as well as the basic techniques for commercial song writing. Students will score a large group arrangement and a big band chart for eight brass, five saxophones and four rhythm section players.

name: Advanced Jazz Musicianship
description: Instruction covers implementing jazz harmony, chord symbols, jazz scales and modes, jazz articulations, and techniques for accurately memorizing jazz standards. Lessons focus on implementing these concepts in jazz performances. This course uses the music of the blues, jazz standards, and contemporary music as "play along" tools.

name: Class Guitar
description: Introduction to playing the guitar which assumes no prior instruction. There is no previous experience required, and all students who have expressed a desire to learn how to play the guitar are welcome.

name: Class Guitar 2
description: Class Guitar 2 is an intermediate level group class teaching students that have had prior guitar experience or have taken Class Guitar 1 (beginner level). Prior experience or skill is necessary and the course is open to all students regardless of major.
